prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling a preteen that they likely aren't trans and should not self diagnose themselves?
Posting from an alt because these people know my handle and I would prefer to hear from other's opinions.

I recently got banned from a discord chat. The moderator's reasoning? "We will not tolerate Homophobes."

Now, I am banned. I don't have the chat logs to pull up, and this was a semi-private discord, so I don't have a valid key to take an alt into to get them. Sucks, right? Here's what I remember saying, since I do have word opened with my reply and research.

---

Basically, this kid in this server started complaining about the fact that their parents weren't letting them get hormone therapy for being trans. This kid has talked about it before on the server, and from my understanding they have never actually seen a psychologist in regards to this. They just "felt" they were trans.

So, I called them out. I started asking questions. "How old are you?" (15 she said) "Why do you want this?" (Coz itll make me feel better!) "Have you seen a psychologist?" (No, but I've heard what it's like and I feel the same way!)

By the time I actually managed to get them to say that last one, the rest of the server was butting in, basically saying that I was a "complete fucking asshole for asking stuff like that" and that "You don't need to have a slip of paper to be valid!"

Finally, I just wrote up one big reply (because at this point I was getting bombarded with people harassing me) which expressed my view. It went as follows:

---

Are you guys serious?

Less than 1% of the population experiences Gender Dysphoria, according to the 2013 Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. The highest I've read is an estimated 0.5% of the population according to a 2014 study (1), however, most estimates point to the “real number” being FAR lower than that, often less than 0.1%.

Of those, research shows that most (I've read lower estimates of 60-70%, but The American Collage of Pediatricians states this is closer to 80-90% (2)) will not experience Gender Dysphoria after Puberty. (3) Of the remaining minority, most will have another kind of mental illness alongside Dysphoria.

As I've mentioned here before, I have a mental illness that encompasses 2% of the world population. I have met one other person with my own condition outside of forums, servers, and communities built for people with that condition. So for Gender Dysphoria – and therefore Trans people – to have such a high vocal presence online... It's absolutely staggering. To be honest, to me this means that *most* people who say they are trans, simply are not. It also means that many people, like Hush, are simply going to falsely self diagnose.

From my experience, I feel something else is at work, that some people are lying, or that there are other forces at play – and many researchers seem to agree, often stating that many people seem to confuse other illnesses, simple anxiety, or puberty as dysphoria.

This is exactly why y'all shouldn't be so eager to support <TRANS KID>! This is why I'm asking questions! Because in all likelihood, from what she's told us, <TRANSKID> LIKELY ISN'T TRANS.

Stop linking me to tumblr pages ffs. Read some actual god damn articles and crap on this. Believe it or not, some teenagers online are not the be-all-end-all of how the world works.

(1) Transgender Demographics: A Household Probability Sample of US Adults, 2014.
Crissman HP, Berger MB, Graham LF, Dalton VK
Am J Public Health. 2017 Feb; 107(2):213-215.

(2) https://www.acpeds.org/the-college-speaks/position-statements/gender-dysphoria-in-children

(3) https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18981931/

---

It got a few middle finger emotes, then it was deleted, I got the message from a mod, and then I was banned before I could reply.

Am I the asshole? Was I right to be banned for this? Am I seriously a homophobe for calling someone out on what is likely nothing more than prepubescent bullshit?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out whether the author is in the wrong for telling a preteen that they're not trans and shouldn't self-diagnose. Let me break this down.

First, the situation: The author is in a Discord server where a 15-year-old is talking about wanting hormone therapy because they think they're trans. The author questions them, points out they haven't seen a psychologist, and then writes a detailed response with statistics about gender dysphoria rates and how most kids outgrow it. The community reacts negatively, calling the author an asshole, and they get banned as a homophobe.

The main issue here is whether the author was wrong to question the kid's self-diagnosis. Let's consider the arguments for both sides.

On one hand, the author is concerned about the kid possibly misdiagnosing themselves, using statistical data to argue that most people who say they're trans aren't actually experiencing gender dysphoria, and that many outgrow it. They mention mental health research and their own experience with a rare mental illness to support their point. The author's intention might be to encourage the kid to seek professional help rather than jump into hormone therapy, which is a big step. From a medical perspective, self-diagnosis can be problematic, especially for something as complex as gender identity. The author might be trying to protect the kid from potential harm by not rushing into medical decisions without proper evaluation.

On the other hand, the way the author presented their argument could be seen as dismissive and invalidating. The tone of the message, including phrases like "likely isn't trans," "prepubescent bullshit," and the implication that the kid is lying or confused, could come across as hostile. Even if the author's intention was to help, the approach might have been harmful. Trans youth often face a lot of skepticism and invalidation, and questioning their identity without proper context or sensitivity can be damaging. Additionally, the author generalized statistics about gender dysphoria to an individual case, which might not be appropriate. Each person's experience is unique, and using statistics to dismiss someone's identity can be seen as a form of transphobia or at least transmisogyny, especially when directed at a minor.

Another point to consider is the community's reaction. The server members defended the kid, suggesting that they don't need a diagnosis to be valid. This reflects the current cultural emphasis on self-identification in the trans community. While some argue that medical professionals should be involved in the transition process, others believe that individuals should have autonomy over their identity. The author's approach might have crossed a line by not respecting the kid's self-identification and instead implying they're not valid, which can contribute to a hostile environment for trans youth.

Also, the author's use of phrases like "homophobe" as a slur from the moderators might be a misunderstanding. Homophobia typically refers to fear or hatred of LGBTQ+ people, but if the author is questioning a specific identity without attacking the person's worth, it's more about skepticism or concern rather than hatred. However, the way it was communicated could be perceived as discriminatory, leading to the ban.

In terms of the statistics cited, while they might be accurate, applying them to an individual case isn't valid. Just because many people experience dysphoria that resolves doesn't mean this kid is in that group. The author's conclusion that "most people who say they're trans aren't" is a generalization that can be harmful. It's possible the kid is genuinely experiencing dysphoria, and the author's response could discourage them from seeking help or expressing their identity.

Moreover, the author's response may have been condescending. The part where they mention their own rare illness and compare it to gender dysphoria (suggesting that if it's rare, the vocal presence online is disproportionate) might be minimizing the kid's experience. That comparison could be seen as invalidating.

In summary, while the author's concern about the kid's self-diagnosis might have a basis in some research, the way they expressed it—disparagingly, with statistical generalizations, and a dismissive tone—likely contributed to an environment that's not supportive of the trans youth. The community's reaction and the ban suggest that the author's approach was not appropriate, even if their intention was to caution against self-diagnosis. The line between concern and transphobia can be thin, and in this case, the author's message crossed it by being invalidating and potentially harmful.
